To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

1
o
Junij
1591
M
r
Thomas Bodelely. to my L.

page.lettertext:
fol.97r
May it please yo
r
good L. I receaved this
day her
Ma
ties
letter, wherof
e date was omitted,
w
t
two from yo
r
L. of
e 12 and 21 of May.
by w
ch
I am required to deale w
t
e
states
about
e abuse of their traffique: and w
t
e
Councel
of state
both in that, and
e maters of
Ostend,
as
also w
t
others in affaires of other qualitie.
To
e General states, w
ch
are heere remaining,
I will resort at their first assembly. Howbeit
the Councel of state, as I have formerly written,
is departed hens, and resideth at
Zutphen,
re-
pairing daily to
e Campe, as occasions are pre-
sented. I had bin w
t
them long er this, as they
have often required by their letters unto me, but
because
e General states continue still heere,
and I had not heard from yo
r
L. sins
e 9 of
April, for w
ch
I expected somwhat by
e first,
to be imparted unto them, I thought to attend
the receat of my next from yo
r
L. And nowe
what ans wear shall be made by
e states in this place,
I will certifie from hens: and depart im-
mediatly upon it to
e Councel of state, whose
answear in like maner I will presently re-
turne. And for
e recoverie of those bookes
and specialties, w
ch
were brought out of
Spaine,
I
have already dispatched
M
r
Gilpin
towardes
Amsterdam,
w
t
so sufficient instruction, as I
hope; if they be to be had, yo
r
L. desire shall
be thorowly accomplished. The opportunitie
of this bearer doth cause me to signifie somwhat
thus in general upon
e sight of my letters. The
bearers name is
Christopher Kennet
an officer
of
S
r
Thomas Shirley
, deputed for
e paiment of the
companies in field, and
e Garrisons of
Flushing
fol.97v
and
Berghen,
as likewise for
e sending of mony
to
e
Brille
and Ostend. In respect of his charge
in these contreis I thought it not impertinent to
name him to yo
r
L. and to certifie w
t
all,
at
to my understanding, and in
e common opinion
of all
at looke into his dealing, his diligence
and discretion doth deserve a better testimony,
then I have presently occasion to yelde in his
behalf. And although I thinke S
r
Thomas Shirley
hath some cause of importance, to calle him home
for a time, yet for avoiding inconvenience, if
e troupes at
e campe be not duly provided,
wherein I am required by this Councel to use
all meanes of prevention, his speedy dispatche
will be greatly requisit. There is
no other occurrence, sins
e writing of my last
e 22 of May. This is only expected, that
o
r
forces being approched w
t
in half Canon shotte
of
e walles of
Deventer,
we shall heare by
e
first some good successe of
e batterie. The
Enemie we learne doth assemble all his forces,
in all quarters, w
t
intent to remove
e siege
to w
ch
effect, as letters report that come to this
place, he hath fully appeased w
t
paiment
e
mutins of
Diest
and
Herentals.
And
so
for
this present I take my humble leave.
From
e Hage. 1 Junij 1591.
Yo
r
L most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley.
At this very instant advertisment is
come hither, that yesterday morning
e towne
of Deventer yelded, upon like composition
as
e towne of Zutphen. It was first battered,
a breache made, and an assault given, in w
ch
the
Englishe forces came so hotly forward, as they lost
about 30 men,
e breache being insufficient.
But
e
Count
endevouring by an other batterie
to make a larger entrance, they surrendred.
This is signified unto us by a speedy letter
promising by
e next suche further particularities as passed.
